results.title: High-speed motion picture of the human vocal chords
results.brief_description: Speech, to the telephone engineer, is a commodity that must be picked up in one place and delivered promptly, cheaply and in good condition to another. For a number of years members of the Bell Telephone Laboratories have been investigating the properties of speech and this film shows the use of high-speed motion picture photography in this important area.

results.title: Hideous kinky
results.creator_credit: Gillies MacKinnon, Ann Scott, BBC Film Unit and Film Consortium
results.brief_description: In an era about ‘love’ and the spiritual quest for the individual, young English mother of two Julia (Kate Winslet) goes on a journey with her two young children to live in Marrakech, Morocco 1972. Based on the novel by Esther Freud (daughter of painter Lucien) and told from the perspective of the youngest daughter, Julia throws herself into the local culture and with barely the means to support her girls with food and shelter. She is match-made by the children to a street performer and dubious local Bilal (Said Taghmaoui) and they soon become a couple. Exotic and enticing, more a visual feast than a dramatic quest, the film may challenge viewers’ notions of parenting, self-fulfilment and ultimately love. Some may just love the exotic travelogue nature that is the background of the Moroccan location. Soundtrack includes some memorable hits from the British charts of the 1960s/70s. The two performers in the roles of the daughters are captivating - eight year old Bea (Bella Riza) and six year old Lucy (Carrie Mullan) who are tired of mum’s adventures and just want to be ‘normal’. Directed by Gillies MacKinnon, with screenplay by his brother Billy MacKinnon.

results.title: Hidden universe: the brain. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Tom Bywaters, CRM/McGraw-Hill Films and American Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: Discusses the cause of aphasia and shows experiments with infants which test their cognitive development and general learning patterns. Also includes a study of visial perception and the advances being made toward giving sight to the blind, as well as looking at a variety of brain malfunctions and current treatment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Bywaters, CRM/McGraw-Hill Films and American Broadcasting Company

results.title: Hidden universe: the brain. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Tom Bywaters, CRM/McGraw-Hill Films and American Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of the functions of the brain, including motor control, memory and sensory perceptions. Shows doctors performing a craniotomy, probing different parts of the brain, and indicating the sensations that this causes. Discusses the separate functions of the left and right sides of the brain.

results.title: Hidden treasures
results.creator_credit: David Gill, Kevin Brownlow and Thames Production
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Unknown Chaplin”.
Featuring Charlie Chaplin in previously unseen home movies, scenes from abandoned films and scenes cut from release prints of the classics “City Lights” and “Modern Times”. Narrated by James Mason.

results.title: Hidden treasure : thoughts about living with Turner's Syndrome : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description:
Turner’s Syndrome affects one in every 2000-2500 females. A genetic disorder due to the absence of an X chromosome, it usually leads to growth difficulties, infertility and, in some cases, learning difficulties, particularly with mathematics and spatial relationships.
These twelve stories are by those who have lived with Turner’s Syndrome, either by being diagnosed with it or caring for a child with the disorder. The inspiring stories are about living with Turner’s Syndrome and not letting it prevent them from living a normal life.
